testCase.expectations:
- titles should include broad topics like "Ciência da Computação", "Programação", "Desenvolvimento de Software"
      - may include other related topics to coding and programming
      - all titles and descriptions in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - Focus only on title field, no need to pay attention to the description
  - It's okay for description to have issues, focus on the title
  - The description should NOT have an impact on scoring unless it's written in the wrong language
  - Title should NOT have level/joiner words like "basic", "intermediate", "advanced", "fundamentals", etc
  - Title should NOT have words like "course" in the title
  - Titles are in Title Case
  - Not following title guidelines is a major error

steps.conclusion: None. Titles are in Brazilian Portuguese, use Title Case, avoid levels/joiners, include both "Física" and "Química" separately, and do not use "Física e Química" as a single title.

Slight orthography mismatch for Brazilian Portuguese: "Físico-Química" is more commonly written as "Fisicoquímica" in Brazil; the physics description references chemical transformations, which is a mild mismatch but acceptable given the guidance to focus on titles.

Use the Brazilian form "Fisicoquímica"; optionally expand with relevant subfields (e.g., "Mecânica", "Termodinâmica", "Eletromagnetismo", "Química Orgânica", "Química Inorgânica", "Química Analítica") for broader coverage; tailor descriptions to each domain more precisely.

Two titles use "the Beatles" instead of the official proper noun capitalization "The Beatles" ("History of the Beatles" and "Cultural Impact of the Beatles"); one title, "Beatles Music," sounds slightly unnatural compared to common course naming conventions.
